sn42.10:1.1: A century after the Buddha, the use of money by the mendicants of Vesālī precipitated a crisis in the Saṅgha. This led to the Second Council, at which the prohibition was reaffirmed. The current discourse is one of several cited against the use of money (Kd 22:1.4.1).
sn42.10:1.3: Literally “gold and silver” (jātarūparajata), but rajata is explained in Bu NP 18:2.8 as currency made from any material that serves as a medium of exchange.
sn42.10:2.1: Despite his impressive name (“Jeweled Crest”), this chief does not appear elsewhere.
sn42.10:3.6: This principle is still followed today. Mendicants generally should not ask for things. But they may ask for necessities from appropriate people, such as monastery attendants, people who have offered an invitation, or relatives.
